questions.text: An epidemiologist plans to conduct a prospective study instead of a retrospective study. Which of the following disadvantages does he aim to eliminate by conducting this study?
questions.solution:
Recall bias can be eliminated in a prospective study.

Memory or recall bias: When cases and controls are asked questions about their past history, it may be more likely for the cases to recall the existence of certain events or factors, than the controls who are healthy persons. For example, those who have had a myocardial infarction might be more likely to remember and recall certain habits or events than those who have not. Thus cases may have a different recall of past events than controls.

Prospective studies begin in the present and continue into future. Hence there will be minimal change for recall bias.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

  • Bias due to confounding: It can be removed by matching.
  • Memory or recall bias as cases and controls may not be able to recall specifics about their history.
  • Selection bias: Cases and controls may not be representative of the population or there may be systematic differences between both.
  • Berkesonian bias: This type of selection bias occurs in hospital cases and controls as the admission rates for people with different diseases may differ.
  • Interviewer’s bias: If the interviewer knows the hypothesis and who the cases are, he/she may interview the cases more thoroughly than the controls. It can be eliminated by double blinding.
  • Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias: It is due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. For example, a case-control study is carried out to study the relation between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI), being cases interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Related Pearl: Blinding in Epidemiology

  • Blinding is done in epidemiology to reduce the possibility of bias.
  • Types
    • In single blind trials, only the participants or group members are not aware of the group allocation.
    • In double blind trials, both the group members and the observers are not aware of the group allocation.
    • In triple blind trials, the group members, the observers and the analyzers are unaware of the group allocation.
  • The most commonly used type of blinding is double blinding.

The phases of a clinical trial and their objectives are as given below.

Phase 1 (first in humans) is carried out in 10-100 participants. It aims to test the safety and tolerability of the drug. Usually, healthy volunteers are chosen. Sometimes patients with an advanced or rare disease are also considered. It generally lasts for 1-2 years.

Phase 2 (first in patients) checks the efficacy and dose-ranging of the drug. 50-500 patient subjects receive the experimental drug. It lasts for 2-3 years.

Phase 3 (multisite trial) is carried out for confirmation of the efficacy tested in phase 2. The indications are finalized and guidelines for therapeutic use are formulated. A few hundred to a few thousand patient subjects receive the drug. It lasts for around 3-5 years.

Phase 4 (postmarketing surveillance) tests for adverse effects, or those that occur only after long-term use and drug interactions. It is done in patients already on treatment with the approved drug. There is no fixed duration for this stage.

questions.text: A statistician is working on a study about the hemoglobin status of children in an area. He plotted the frequency distribution as shown below.  Which of the following is most likely to be the mean, median, and mode, respectively of the same?
questions.solution:
The image given shows a positively/ right-skewed distribution where mean> median> mode. Hence, the mean, median, and mode must be 11, 9, and 7 respectively. None of the other options have such a sequence.

The observed value that occurs with the greatest frequency is known as the mode. If there are two values that occur with the same greatest frequency, the distribution is bimodal. If there are more than two such values, the distribution becomes multimodal. 

When all the values are listed in order, the value that divides the distribution in half is known as the median. When there are an even number of values, the median is obtained by calculating the mean of the two middle scores.

The mean (average) is obtained by summing up all the values and dividing the obtained sum by the total number of values in the distribution.

Skewed distributions are the ones that have asymmetric frequency distributions. They can be identified as positive (right) or negative (left) according to the location of the tail of the curve.

In the image, the tail is located on the positive side of the graph (right side) and so it is a positively or right-skewed distribution. A positively skewed data set contains a large number of low scores but a small number of very high scores. It is vice versa in negatively skewed distributions.

The mean in a positively skewed distribution is pulled up because of the relatively small number of very high scores. The mode is the most frequent and the highest point on the curve, while the median lies between the mean and mode. 

Other options:

Option A: Mean= median= mode is seen in a normal (unimodal) distribution.

Option C: Mean< median< mode is seen in a negatively skewed distribution.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (b) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (c) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (a) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: According to the national framework for malaria elimination in India, states were categorized based on ______.
questions.solution:
The annual parasite incidence (API) is used to categorize states/union territories under the national framework for malaria elimination in India.

The national framework for malaria elimination in India was launched in February 2016 with the following goals:

  • Eliminate malaria throughout the entire country by 2030
  • Maintain malaria-free status in areas where transmission has been interrupted and prevent re-introduction

It uses the annual parasite index to classify states/union territories into four categories.

  • Category 0 (Prevention of re-establishment phase): States/union territories with zero cases
  • Category 1 (Elimination phase): States/union territories with all their districts having API <1
  • Category 2 (pre-elimination phase): States/union territories with API <1, but some of their districts having API≥1
  • Category 3 (Intensified control phase): States/union territories with API≥1

API is calculated by the formula: confirmed cases during one year X 1000 / population under surveillance.

Regions with API≥ 2 are considered high-risk areas and are eligible for vector control.

Other options:

Option B: Slide positivity rate is used to describe the percentage of slides positive for the malarial parasite. The type of species is not taken into account.

Option C: Slide falciparum rate is the percentage of slides that are positive for Plasmodium falciparum species. 

Option D: Annual blood examination rate is derived by the formula - number of slides examined X 100/ Population. It is considered an index of operational efficiency.

questions.text:
Match the following thermometers with their applications.
Type of thermometer Application
1. Dry bulb thermometer  A. The mean radiant temperature
2. Globe thermometer  B. The cooling capacity of the working environment
3. Wet globe thermometer  C. Low air velocities
4. Kata thermometer  D. The air temperature
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, and 4-C.

A dry bulb thermometer is an ordinary thermometer used to measure the air temperature. It is mounted on the Stevenson screen for accurate readings.

A globe thermometer can be used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings. It is affected by both the air temperature and radiant heat.

A wet globe thermometer is used for measuring environmental heat. It exchanges heat with the surroundings by conduction, convection, evaporation, and radiation. The equilibrium temperature of the globe provides a comprehensive measure of the cooling capacity of the work environment.

A kata thermometer was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air. It was used to assess the indices of thermal comfort. Currently, it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities. 

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

  • A number of thermometers which employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.
  • These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.
  • The instruments used to measure air temperature are:
    • Dry bulb thermometers:
      • These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level
    • Wet bulb thermometers
      • These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.
    • Maximum thermometer
      • This is a mercury thermometer which has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb
    • Minimum thermometer
      • The liquid in this thermometer is spirit which has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it
    • Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer
      • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
      • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
      • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available
  • Globe thermometer:
    • It is used for the direct measurement of mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
    • It has a hollow metal bulb (6 inches diameter) which has a matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
    • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.
  • Kata thermometers:
    • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
    • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
    • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: A study was done to assess nutritional status among young children in rural and urban areas. 40 children in rural and 30 children in urban areas were malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate test of significance, in this case, is the chi-square test. It is used to compare qualitative data between 2 groups with independent measures.

In this question,

  • Nutritional status (nourished or malnourished) is a qualitative measure.
  • Residence (Urban or rural) is again a qualitative measure.
  • Further, only these TWO variables are being compared. Therefore, the chi-square test is the most appropriate test of significance.

The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increase.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test can also be used.

Other options:

Option B: The paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. If a study were to compare BP in a group of patients before and after treatment, then paired t-test would be used. It is also a test done for quantitative variables.

Option C: Standard error of the mean measures how much discrepancy is likely in a sample's mean compared with the population mean. It is not a test for statistical significance.

Option D: The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between means of two or more than two groups. Hence it is used in studies with quantitative data. If a study was done to compare the heights of boys in different classes in a school, ANOVA would be used.

questions.text: A patient with Wilm's tumor undergoes renal transplantation. He is currently on corticosteroid therapy to prevent organ rejection. All of the following vaccinations could be given to this patient except?
questions.solution:
Intra-nasal/ nasal spray influenza vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine, therefore it is contraindicated in this patient as he is immunosuppressed.

Live vaccines are prepared from live or wild attenuated organisms. They are repeatedly passed through tissue cultures or chick embryos in the laboratory. With this, they lose their ability to induce full-blown infection in an individual but retain their immunogenicity. It should not be administered to patients with immunodeficiency diseases, lymphoma, leukaemia, or other malignancies. It is also not recommended in individuals on treatment with corticosteroids, antimetabolites, and alkylating agents. Unless the risk of infection exceeds the risk of harm, it is contraindicated in pregnancy. 

Live- attenuated influenza vaccine is approved for use in otherwise healthy individuals between age of 2 years and 49 years. Because the risk of transmission of the live-attenuated vaccine virus to immunocompromised individuals is unknown, it should not be used in household members of immunosuppressed individuals, health care workers, or others with close contact with immunosuppressed persons.

Intramuscular influenza vaccine is an inactivated vaccine, which can be given in the immunocompromised.

Other options:

Option A: Diptheria-pertussis-tetanus (DPT) vaccine is a combination toxoid vaccine. The toxins produced by diphtheria and tetanus bacilli are detoxicated and used to prepare the vaccine. They are highly efficacious and safe. The killed whole organism is used for the pertussis component. 

Option B: Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine. It is produced by inserting a viral gene segment into a yeast cell. It does not contain viral DNA and will not produce an infection.

Option D: Inactivated polio vaccine is a killed vaccine. As the organism cannot grow in a vaccinated individual, it can be given to an immunodeficient individual.

questions.text: The quality of drinking water is considered to be satisfactory if the presumptive coliform count is:
questions.solution:
According to WHO guidelines, the quality of drinking water is considered to be satisfactory if the presumptive coliform count is 0/100 mL.

Drinking water should not contain any pathogenic organisms or bacteria indicative of faecal contamination. The primary bacterial indicator used to assess this is the coliform group of organisms. This is because they are present abundantly in the human intestine and can be easily detected by culture methods. 

The presumptive coliform test can be done by the multiple tube method or membrane filtration techniques. In the multiple-tube method, the water to be tested is inoculated into tubes containing a suitable liquid medium. These tubes are then incubated for 48 hours and examined. The test is called presumptive because the reaction observed in the tube may occasionally be due to other organisms. The presumption that the reaction is due to coliform organisms has to be confirmed. McConkey's lactose bile salt broth with bromocresol purple 25 as an indicator is used as the media. Escherichia coli or thermotolerant coliform bacteria should not be detected in any 100 ml sample. 

In samples of chlorinated water, confirmation of the presumptive test is necessary. This is done by subculturing the positive tubes in two tubes of brilliant green bile broth. It is based on the fact that E.Coli is the only coliform that can produce gas from lactose at 44°C.

Supplementary indicator organisms include fecal streptococci and sulfite-reducing clostridia. 

Related Pearl: WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

I) Physical parameters

 

  Guideline values Comments
Turbidity Ideally, there should be no visible turbidity but permissible standard is < 1.0 NTU for household drinking water.  Expressed in nephelometric turbidity units (NTU). It describes the cloudiness of water. >4 NTU – cloudiness visible to naked eye. <4 NTU – measured only by instruments. 
Color Ideally, there should be no visible color but permissible standard is <15 TCU. Expressed in true color units (TCU). >15 TCU is detectable by naked eye. 
Taste and odor No health based guideline value has been proposed. It may be indicative of contamination and pollution. The cause must be investigated.
Temperature No health based guideline value has been proposed. Cool water is generally more palatable. High water temperature may enhance the growth of microorganisms and influence taste, odor and color.

 

II) Chemical parameters

  Guideline values Comments
Ammonia No health based guideline value has been proposed as it occurs in drinking water at concentrations well below those of health concern. Natural levels in surface and ground water is 0.2 mg/l. Anaerobic groundwater may have up to 3 mg/l.
Aluminium 0.9 mg/l There is very less evidence that aluminium in drinking water causes toxic effects.
Arsenic 0.01 mg/l Levels in natural water range from 1 to 2 µg/l.
Chloride 250 mg/l, as above this a detectable taste appears. Maximum permissible level is 600 mg/litre. Sodium thiosulphate can be used to dechlorinate drinking water or tap water.
Copper 2 mg/l Excess copper in water can have gastrointestinal effects and other adverse effects in people without normal copper homeostasis.
Fluoride 1.5 mg/l Above this guideline value, there is risk of dental fluorosis and skeletal fluorosis. Artificial fluoridation range is 0.5 to 1.0 mg/l.
Hydrogen sulphide Taste and odor threshold is between 0.05 and 0.1 mg/litre. A rotten egg smell of water indicates hydrogen sulphide.
Nitrates 50 mg/l as nitrate ion, to prevent against methaemoglobinaemia and thyroid effects in susceptible populations  This guideline
value is based on the absence of adverse health effects (methaemoglobinaemia
and thyroid effects) at concentrations below 50 mg/L in epidemiological studies.
Nitrites 3 mg/l as nitrite ion, to prevent against methemoglobinemia in infants and the general population. Bottle-fed infant are at higher risk.
pH Acceptable pH is in the range of 6.5 – 8.5. ______
Lead 0.01 mg/l The concentration of lead must be kept as low as possible. It is the most undesirable metal in drinking water.
Mercury 0.006 mg/l for inorganic mercury Nephrotoxicity is the main effect of mercury toxicity.
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) Benzo(a)pyrene at 0.0007 mg/l They are to be kept in traces as they are carcinogenic/mutagenic.
Sodium Above 200 mg/l may give unacceptable taste. _________
Total Dissolved Solids (TDS) Less than 600 mg/l is generally considered palatable. TDS consists of inorganic salts and small amounts of organic matter dissolved in water. Water is completely unpalatable above 1200mg/l.

 

III) Biological indicators

  • Total coliform bacteria:
    • They are the primary bacterial indicators for drinking water.
    • They include a range of aerobic and facultative anaerobic, Gram-negative, non-spore-forming bacilli capable of fermenting lactose to acid or aldehyde at 35 to 37 degree Celsius within 24 hours. They include fecal and environmental organisms from wide genera.
    • E. coli and thermotolerant coliforms are a subset of the total coliform groups and they ferment lactose at 44 – 45 degrees Celsius and have the ability to produce indole.
    • Total coliforms are good indicators of water disinfection because they are abundant in the human intestine and are foreign to potable water.
    • E. coli is considered the best indicator of fecal contamination of water when resources for supplementary microbiological examination are limited.
    • Guidelines state that coliforms must not be detectable in 100ml of sample water. 
    • Multiple tubes method:
      • This is a test of bacteriological surveillance of drinking water for coliforms and thereby fecal contamination.
      • This test is based on the most probable number (MPN) of coliform organisms.
      • Acid and gas production from fermentation due to coliforms are observed for in multiple tubes and a presumptive coliform count is arrived at.
      • Confirmation of E. coli can be done by testing for indole formation at 44-45 degrees Celsius or by another test called Eijkman test.
    • Faecal streptococci:
      • They are used as an indicator of fecal pollution.
      • Their presence in water indicates recent contamination with feces and are regarded as specific indicators of human faecal pollution.
    • Clostridium perfringens:
      • They are spore-forming organisms which are resistant to many disinfection methods.
      • They are used as an indicator of protozoa in water and also of remote/intermittent fecal contamination.
      • Their spores are also indicators of the effectiveness of filtration processes.
    • Viruses like enteric viruses can also be used as indicators of the disinfection process and of the presence of other contaminants in the water.
    • Heterotrophic plate counts are indicators of disinfection and distribution of water. It measures a wide range of heterotrophic organisms including bacteria and fungi.
    • Coliphages and Bacteroides fragilis phages are evidences of fecal contamination of water.

 

IV) Radiological aspects

  • Becquerel (Bq) is the unit used for radioactivity.
  • In the case of drinking water, the concentration of radioactivity is referred to as Bq/litre.
  • Proposed guidelines for gross alpha activity is 0.5 Bq/litre and for gross beta activity is 1.0 Bq/litre of drinking water.

questions.text: An epidemiologist gives a lecture on pandemics. He cites the influenza pandemic as an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The influenza pandemic is an example of a cyclical trend.

A cyclical trend is a type of periodic fluctuation. It occurs in cycles that are spread over short periods of time. This can be days, weeks, months, or even years. Influenza pandemics are known to occur at intervals of 7- 10 years, due to antigenic variations. Some non-infectious conditions can also display cyclical trends. An example of this is road traffic accidents occurring more frequently on the weekends. Knowledge of the cyclical pattern of diseases can be used to protect communities against the same.

Other options:

Option A: Seasonal trend is a type of period fluctuation which refers to seasonal variation of diseases. Examples of diseases that follow this trend include measles, malaria, and upper respiratory tract infections. It can be related to environmental conditions such as temperature and humidity. Some non-infectious conditions which follow this trend are sunstroke, hay fever, and snakebite.

Option B: Secular or long-term trend signifies the changes seen in the occurrence of a disease over a long period of time. It implies a consistent change in a particular direction such as a progressive increase or decrease. Examples of conditions that follow this pattern are coronary heart disease and lung cancer which have shown a consistent upward trend. A decline in the occurrence of diseases such as tuberculosis and diphtheria has been noted in developed countries. 

Option C: Point-source epidemic is a type of common-source epidemic. In this type of epidemic, there are no secondary waves and the epidemic curve rises and falls rapidly. There is a clustering of cases within a narrow interval of time. All the cases develop within one incubation period of the specific disease.

questions.text: At PHCs, vaccines are stored in:
questions.solution:
Ice-lined refrigerators (ILRs) are the main method of vaccine storage in primary health centres (PHCs).

ILRs are an important part of the cold chain and they maintain a temperature of 2 to 8 degree Celsius for storage of vaccines. They have different temperature zones for different vaccines and they are stored accordingly in the baskets that are provided in most ILRs. Dial or digital thermometers are used to record temperatures inside an ILR.

Inside the ILR there is a lining of water containers (ice packs or tubes) fitted all around the walls. When the refrigerator is functioning the water in the containers freezes and cools the cabinet. When the electricity supply fails, then the ice lining maintains the inside temperature of the refrigerator at a safe level for vaccines. Therefore, the temperature is maintained in ILR for a much longer duration than in the deep freezers and domestic refrigerators. Thus ILR is an ideal option for safe storage of vaccines.

questions.text: If  the sensitivity and specificity  of a screening test are 90% and 95% respectively, calculate the positive likelihood ratio:
questions.solution:
The positive likelihood ratio of this screening test is 18.

A positive likelihood ratio, or LR+, is the probability that a positive test would be expected in a patient with a disease divided by the probability that a positive test would be expected in a patient without a disease. In other words, an LR+ is the true positivity rate divided by the false positivity rate.

Positive Likelihood Ratio= Sensitivity/(1-Specificity) 

LR+= 0.9/1-0.95= 0.9/0.05 = 18.

Similarly , Negative Likelihood Ratio= (1- Sensitivity)/Specificity

questions.text: The non-communicable disease (NCD)  clinic at the district hospital screens people above the age of 50 years with positive family history for diabetes.  What type of screening is this?
questions.solution:
The non-communicable disease/ NCD clinic at the district hospital screening people above the age of 50 years for diabetes is a type of high-risk screening. 

Screening is searching or testing for diseases or defects that are not evident in apparently healthy individuals. High-risk or selective screening is screening applied selectively to high-risk groups defined on the basis of epidemiological research. For example, screening the other members in families of patients with diabetes or hypertension that tend to aggregate in families. It is an effective and economical method of screening.  

Other options:

Option A: Mass screening is the screening of a population or a sub-group of the population for a disease irrespective of the particular risk an individual may run of contracting the disease in question. It is not a useful preventive measure unless there is a  suitable treatment that alters the duration or outcome of a disease.

Option B: Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests (instead of carrying out separate screening tests for a single disease) to a large number of people in the form of health questionnaires, clinical examinations, and investigations. It has not shown any benefit to the population in terms of mortality and morbidity reduction and has instead increased the cost of health services.

Option C: Prospective screening is screening people for the benefit of others. For example, screening immigrants for infectious diseases such as tuberculosis to protect the home population from the disease.

Note: Prescriptive screening is defined as the presumptive screening of patients for unrecognized diseases for their own benefit. It usually does not arise from a patient's request. Examples include screening for bacteriuria in pregnancy and screening for hemolytic disease in a neonate.

questions.text: You conduct a study to determine the association between computer use and visual impairment and get a correlation coefficient of +0.4. Which of the following scattergrams best represents your findings?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario having a correlation coefficient of +0.4 shows a positive weak correlation and the scattergram that best represents this finding is graph number 2.

Correlation is used to assess the strength and direction of the association between two variables (such as smoking and lung cancer). The correlation coefficient (denoted by r) is represented by a plus or minus sign, followed by a number (Example: -0.88). The correlation coefficient ranges from -1 to +1.

The numerical indicates the strength of correlation:

  • Correlation coefficients greater than ± 0.5 are considered strong and are likely to establish (if positive correlation) or disprove (if negative correlation) the association between two factors.
  • Correlation coefficients between 0 and ± 0.5 are regarded as weak.

The sign indicates the direction of the correlation.

  • Plus sign (+) suggests that both the variables being studied are positively correlated. This means that the high value of one variable is associated with a high value in another. An example is an association between salt intake and blood pressure readings.
  • Minus sign (-) suggests that both the variables being studied are negatively correlated. A high value of one variable such as cigarette consumption is associated with a low value of another variable such as life expectancy.

The relationship between two correlated variables can be represented graphically in the form of a scattergram. Each point represents one observation including both the variables and so would be equal to the sample size. 

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient, signified by r.

Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation). Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak. The strength of the relationship is indicated by the size of the coefficient, while its direction is indicated by the sign. The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below.

Examples:

Positive Correlation (+r): High salt intake is associated with high blood pressure.

Negative Correlation (-r): Increase in smoking of tobacco is associated with a decrease in life expectancy. 

No correlation (r=0): Height of a person and his blood group.

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson product-moment correlation
    It is used for data that have continuous intervals like salt intake vs BP to find a linear relationship.
  2. Spearman rank-order correlation
    It is used for data that have discrete ordered intervals like socioeconomic status vs parity to find a linear or non-linear relationship.

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable. For example - If a study finds a correlation (r) of 0.60 between smoking and life expectancy, it could be concluded that (0.6)2 = 0.36, or 36% of the variation in life expectancy in this study is accounted for by smoking.

questions.text: A sexually active woman who was using barrier contraceptives is planning on switching to DMPA injectables. Which of the following is the correct dosage of this contraceptive?
questions.solution:
The dosage for injectable depot-medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) is 150 mg every 3 months.

The mechanism of contraception are

  • Mainly by preventing ovulation
  • Bringing changes in the cervical mucus
  • Making the endometrium hostile

An important advantage is that it does not affect lactation. Therefore it is an important contraceptive  during the postpartum period to space pregnancies. The side-effects of DMPA include weight gain, irregular menstrual bleeding and prolonged infertility after its use.

questions.text: During a cholera outbreak, you are asked to map the geographical distribution of the disease. What is the best method of doing this?
questions.solution:
Dot-density maps are the best way to plot the geographical distribution of diseases.

The image given below shows a dot-density map of London that was plotted during the 1854 outbreak of cholera.

A dot-density map was used by Dr John Snow when a large outbreak of cholera occurred in London in 1854. Initially, it was believed that bad smells/ air from rotting organic matter spread the disease. He demonstrated the link between contaminated drinking water and cholera. He mapped the disease and identified the source to be a contaminated public water pump in Broad Street, London. 

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man living in Nellore, Andhra Pradesh presents with the following lesions on his teeth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image along with the endemic area of Andhra Pradesh is diagnostic of Dental fluorosis.

Dental fluorosis (also termed mottled enamel) is an extremely common disorder, characterized by hypomineralization of tooth enamel caused by ingestion of excessive fluoride during enamel formation.

Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3-5mg/L. It is endemic in parts of India- Andhra Pradesh (Nellore, Nalgonda, Prakasam), Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, Tamil Nadu. 

Mechanism:

  • In the extra-cellular environment of maturing enamel, an excess of fluoride ions alters the rate at which enamel matrix proteins (amelogenin) are enzymatically broken down and the rate at which the subsequent breakdown products are removed.
  • Fluoride may also indirectly alter the action of protease via a decrease in the availability of free calcium ions in the mineralization environment.
  • This results in the formation of enamel with less mineralization.
  • This hypomineralized enamel has altered optical properties and appears opaque and lustreless relative to normal enamel.

Classification:

The two main classification systems which are used in the grading of severity of dental fluorosis are Dean’s system and TF system.

Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: (1.5mg/L) Occurs if excess fluoride is ingested during the period of tooth calcification, i.e. in the first 7 years of life. Best seen on the upper incisors and almost exclusively affects only permanent teeth. It causes mottling on dental enamel, the appearance of chalky-white patches on the teeth, and loss of shine in the early stages. The white spots progressively turn yellow and can even become brown-black. The loss of enamel gives a corroded appearance. 
  • Skeletal fluorosis: (3-6mg/L) Occurs due to the heavy deposition of fluoride in the skeleton. Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity, fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone and these are usually resistant to secondary osteoclastic resorption. This leads to calcium retention, osteosclerosis, and osteophytosis. Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments is characteristic.
  • Crippling fluorosis: (>10mg/L) Can lead to permanent disability. 

Genu valgum and osteoporosis of the lower limb are seen in a newer form of fluorosis in Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh. It is seen in people consuming jawar (sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.

Interventions for Fluorosis 

  • Change the drinking water source with a lower fluoride content (0.5 to 0.8 mg/L). Running surface water contains lower quantities of fluorides than groundwater sources.
  • Chemical treatment in a water treatment plant can be moderately expensive. The National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Nagpur developed a technique for removing fluoride by a chemical treatment called the Nalgonda technique. 
  • Fluoride supplements should not be prescribed for children who drink fluoridated water.
  • The use of fluoride toothpaste in areas of endemic fluorosis is not recommended for children up to 6 years of age

questions.text: An infant was brought to the outpatient department with fever and rash as shown below for the past 2 days. The rash was pleomorphic and first appeared on the trunk.  What is the secondary attack rate of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing a pleomorphic rash are suggestive of chickenpox or varicella infection. The secondary attack rate of varicella infection is 70-90%. 

The secondary attack rate is defined as the probability that disease occurs among susceptible persons following exposure to an infectious person within the range of the incubation period.

Secondary attack rate (SAR) = (Number of exposed or susceptible persons developing the disease within the incubation period x 100)/(Total number of susceptible close contacts). The secondary attack rate measures the communicability of the disease. 

Varicella or chickenpox is a highly infectious disease caused by the varicella-zoster virus. The mode of transmission from person to person is by droplet infection or by droplet nuclei. This virus can cross the placental barrier and cause congenital varicella.

The incubation period is usually 14 -16 days. The clinical course can be divided into 2 stages. The pre-eruptive stage is marked by the sudden onset of mild to moderate fever, back pain, shivering, and malaise. The eruptive stage is characterized by a rash that appears on the day of fever. They first appear on the trunk and then on the face, arms, and legs. It advances quickly through all stages of macule, papule, vesicle, and scab. Rash exhibits a characteristic feature called pleomorphism because all the above stages of rash may be seen simultaneously at one time. 

Most cases of chickenpox are mild and self-limiting. In children, acyclovir decreases symptoms if taken within 24 hours of the start of the rash, but it has no effect on complication rates, and it is not recommended for individuals with normal immune function.

questions.text: A researcher wants to combine twenty different clinical trials to assess the effect of a drug used for Parkinson's disease. Which of the following best explains the type of study conducted?
questions.solution:
The type of study described here is a meta-analysis that involves combining results from multiple studies on a given topic.

Meta-analysis is the quantitative analysis of the results obtained from a systematic review. A systematic review uses certain inclusion and exclusion criteria to review multiple studies. By combining the results of multiple studies, the power of analysis and generalizability is increased.

Other options

Option A:  A cohort study is a type of analytical study that is done to support or refute an association between a suspected cause and disease. It can be prospective, retrospective, or a combination of the two. The cohorts are selected prior to the appearance of the disease being studied in prospective studies. In retrospective studies, the outcome has already occurred before the start of the study.

Option B: A case-control study is another type of analytical study. It is often called retrospective studies. It is a common method used to test causal hypotheses initially. It proceeds from effect to cause. Both the exposure and outcome have already occurred before the start of the study. It has a control and comparison group.

Option D: A randomized control trial (RCT) is used to evaluate methods of treatment and prevention by scientific techniques. By randomization, the participants are divided into two groups - study and control. The former group receives the procedure or intervention while the latter does. This helps to eliminate bias and ensures comparability. 

Related Pearl: Meta-analysis in Research

  • Meta-analysis is a set of statistical techniques for combining quantitative results from multiple studies to produce a summary of empirical knowledge on a given topic.
  • It refers to a method of systematic review.
  • It is one of the most relevant methods in evidence-based medicine and ranks high on the evidence pyramid.
  • Limitations
    • When testing is done before hypothesis generation, spurious results are found.
    • Sample size may be misrepresentative.
    • Publication bias due to suppression of some important information leading to file drawer effect.
    • Heterogeneity of studies may force mashing together of disparate effects and lead to selection bias. This is also called apples and oranges effect.
    • Dissimilarities in control groups.
    • Its validity is dependent on the quality of the systematic review and the original data used.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: What is the best indicator to evaluate obstetric and neonatal care given before and around the time of birth?
questions.solution:
The best indicator to evaluate obstetric and neonatal care given before and around the time of birth is perinatal mortality rate.

Perinatal mortality includes both late fetal death (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths. Hence it is a better indicator of obstetric and neonatal care.

Related Pearl: Perinatal Mortality Rate

  • The term ‘perinatal mortality’ includes both late fetal death (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.
  • Babies chosen for inclusion in perinatal statistics should be above a minimum birth weight (1000g at birth). If the birth weight is not available, a gestation period of at least 28 weeks should be used (as the weight at 28 weeks corresponds to 1000g). If both are not available, then crown to heel length of at least 35cm should be used.
  • Generally, the PMR = Late fetal deaths and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000g at birth x 1000/Total births(live+dead) weighing over 1000g at birth.
  • The PMR is the yard-stick of obstetric and pediatric care before and around the time of birth.
  • The PMR of India (2016) is 24 per 1000 births.
  • The main causes of perinatal mortality are intrauterine and birth asphyxia, low birth weight, birth trauma, and intrauterine/neonatal infections.

Please note that the actual perinatal period commences from the 22nd week of life, but at that time the fetus weighs only about 500g.

Therefore, only for statistical calculations and international comparisons, to calculate the perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is taken, as then the baby weighs about 1000g. As mentioned, babies included in the perinatal statistics must weigh above 1000g.

questions.text: A female patient visits the OPD with complaints of swelling around her eye as shown in the image. Which of the following transmits the organism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The sign shown in the image above is Romana’s sign. It is seen in acute Chagas disease which is caused by the flagellate Trypanosoma cruzi. It is transmitted by the Reduviid bug.

The person can become infected if T. cruzi parasites in the bug feces enter the body through mucous membranes or breaks in the skin. The sleeping person may accidentally scratch or rub the feces into the bite wound, eyes, or mouth. 

Clinically, the infection course of Chagas disease is divided into acute and chronic phases.

In the acute phase, the majority of the patients will be asymptomatic. Fever, regional lymphadenitis, chagoma (localized subcutaneous nodule at the bite site), and the Romana's sign (unilateral swelling of the eyelids) may be seen.

The chronic phase is characterized by the following findings:

  • Chagasic dilated cardiomyopathy with marked bilateral ventricular enlargement. This may lead to congestive heart failure presenting as shortness of breath. Endomyocardial biopsy shows fibrosis and the presence of intracellular parasites.
  • Megaesophagus and megacolon.

questions.text:
Which of the following are considered the best indicators of air pollution?
  1. Sulfur dioxide
  2. Lead
  3. Carbon monoxide
  4. Smoke
  5. Suspended particles
questions.solution:
The best indicators for routine monitoring of air pollution are sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles (1, 4, and 5). 

These indicators are monitored daily and their results are reported to a central agency.

Air pollution is the presence of gases and particulate matter in the atmosphere that affect human health and safety. It is also injurious to animals and vegetation. Indicators of air pollution:

  • Sulfur dioxide
  • Smoke or soiling index
  • Grit and dust measurement (suspended particles)
  • Co-efficient of haze 
  • Air pollution index 

Air pollution in India is monitored by the National Air Quality Monitoring Program (NAMP). This program is sponsored by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB). 

Under the NAMP, four air pollutants are regularly monitored. They are sulfur dioxide (SO2), oxides of nitrogen such as NO2, respirable suspended particulate matter (RSPM/ PM10), and fine particulate matter (PM2.5). Monitoring of meteorological parameters like wind speed and direction, relative humidity, and temperature have also been included with the monitoring of air quality. This monitoring is carried out twice a week. 

The health effects of air pollution can be immediate or delayed. Immediate effects include acute bronchitis and suffocation. Delayed adverse effects are carcinoma of the lung and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Related Pearl: Air Pollution

  • The vertical diffusion of pollutants depends upon the temperature gradient. When there is rapid cooling of the lower atmospheric layers – which is called temperature inversion - due to little vertical diffusion, pollutants and water vapor get trapped in the lower levels of the atmosphere.

  • Common indoor air pollutants include carbon monoxide, PAHs, nitrogen and sulphur oxides, pesticides, asbestos, lead, radon and other biological pollutants. Most these are from coal or fuel combustion. Pollutants like radon, lead, asbestos, etc. are from construction materials, paints and demolition.

    • Stroke

    • Suspended particle matter (SPM) is another indicator widely used
  • In India, National Air Quality Programme sponsored by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) is the main mode of monitoring air pollution.

questions.solution:
The correct statement regarding the mid-day meal program is the meal should provide at least 1/3rd of the daily energy requirement and 1/2 of the daily protein requirement. 

The mid-day meal program (MDMP)/ school lunch program is catered to provide meals for school children. It is offered to school children in an effort to persuade more children to enroll in schools thereby improving children's literacy. It aims to maintain attendance in schools. Currently, it functions under the broad coverage of the minimum needs program. It is run by the Ministry of Education.

The meal provided under the MDMP should only be a supplement and not a substitute for home diets. It must cover at least 1/2 of the total daily protein requirement and 1/3rd of the total daily energy requirement for children in schools. The cost of meals should be reasonably low. The meals should be easy to cook in schools. Locally available foods must be used whenever possible. The menu should be regularly changed to avoid monotony.

The mid-day meal scheme functions under the ministry of Human Resources Development as a centrally sponsored scheme. Under this, a cooked mid-day meal with at least 300 calories and 8-12 grams of protein is provided to all children of classes I-V.

questions.text: A child was encouraged by his parents to follow a healthy lifestyle to prevent obesity. What level of prevention is adopted in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Primordial prevention is adopted in this scenario.

The emergence of risk factors for obesity is prevented by encouraging the child to follow a healthy lifestyle from an early age. This reduces the probability of developing obesity in the future.

Primordial prevention is the prevention of the emergence of risk factors in populations in which they have not yet appeared. Most adult health problems have their origins in childhood. Efforts are directed toward discouraging children from adopting harmful lifestyles. The main intervention in primordial prevention is individual and mass education.

Other options:

Option A: Primary prevention is the action taken before the onset of the disease to prevent the possibility that a disease will ever occur. Here, intervention is initiated in the pre-pathogenesis phase of a disease. It is accomplished by population strategy and high-risk strategy. Examples of primary prevention are immunization and sanitizing hands.

Option C: Secondary prevention is halting the progress of a disease which has already occurred. It aims to halt the progress at its incipient (initial) stage and preventing complications. Intervention is initiated in the early pathogenesis phase. Measures like early diagnosis and treatment are used to arrest the disease progression. Examples of secondary prevention are pap smears for early detection of cervical cancer and mammography to pick up breast cancer.

Option D: Tertiary prevention is the action taken to limit impairment and promote rehabilitation of patients in case of irreversible damage. Intervention is done in the late pathogenesis phase. An example is rehabilitation by providing walking aid for the crippled.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in order of the demographic cycle.

1. Early expanding population

2. Declining population

3. Low stationary population 

4. Late expanding population

5. High stationary population
questions.solution:
The correct order according to the demographic cycle is high stationary population (5) --> early expanding population  (1) --> late expanding population (4) --> low stationary population (3) -->  declining population  (2).

The demographic cycle has 5 stages:

  • Stage 1: High stationary population 
  • Stage 2: Early expanding population 
  • Stage 3: Late expanding population 
  • Stage 4: Low stationary population 
  • Stage 5: Declining population

In a high stationary population, there is a high birth rate and a high death rate that cancel each other and the population remains stationary.

The early expanding population is marked by a decline in the death rate but the birth rate stays constant. Many countries in South Asia and Africa are in this phase. 

In the late expanding population there is a further fall in the death rate, with the birth rate beginning to fall. The population is still increasing due to a net increase in births. India has entered this phase. 

A low stationary population is characterized by low birth and low death rate, and this can result in a stationary population. It has occurred in most industrialized countries as a demographic transition shifting from high birth and high death rates to low birth and low death rates.

A declining population is one where the birth rate is lower than the death rate, causing population decline. Examples include East European countries like Germany and Hungary.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

    • Mortality

      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding 
      • Death rate declines and birth rate remains unchanged
      • Demographic gap starts increasing and then becomes maximum
    • Stage 3 : Late expanding
      • Death rate decline further and birth rate falls
      • India is in this stage, currently
      • Demographic gap starts declining
    • Stage 4 : Low stationary 
      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative
